page.title: 10LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS
page.content: {LANDSCAPE}may be said to be typical of N.Cornwall. Rugged cliffs, grass- topped, with fine sandy beaches below; fields enclosed by vegetation-covered stone walls known as Cornish hedges, many topped with tamarisk or valerian. Few trees. Part of Trevose Golf Club's 18-hole course completes the scene - plus the alarming hole, some 50m. across, from a collapsed cave, near the footpath to Dinas Head. { {BUILDINGS.}Older buildings, including 15th century Harlyn House with 18th cent. dovecote, & 18th century Trevose Farmhouse, are of stone under slate roofs. Similarly the older farm buildings and tollhouse. Two resid- ences, Mother Ivey's Cottage and Cellars, were converted from 'fish cellars' (from the fishing trade.) Harlyn House is at present being restored by its private owner.
